bug.short_desc: [code assist] Bad relevance for constructor proposals (new Thread())

long_desc.thetext:
Broken at least since 3.5.2 (probably since we have constructor proposals)
Content assist after "new Thre" should have "Thread() - java.lang.Thread" as first proposal.
Currently with proposals sorted by relevance, I get "ThreadDeath()", "ThreadLocal()" and "ThreadLocal" first, which are all less relevant for me. After having selected the type "ThreadLocal", that one even moves to 1st position.
Also strange is that there's no "ThreadDeath" type proposal.
Indeed strange. Also, when having new Thread<content assist> it seems to work.

The relevance from JDT Core is too low for those. new Thread() should have the same relevance as new ThreadDeath() (like in the case of type proposals). Also, the constructor proposals must have higher relevance than type proposals (as you can see e.g. ThreadLocal - 27 stands out here).
Threa<content assist> ==> java.util.concurrent.ThreadFactory - 24 java.util.concurrent.ThreadLocalRandom - 24 java.lang.management.ThreadMXBean - 24 java.lang.management.ThreadInfo - 24 org.omg.PortableServer.THREAD_POLICY_ID - 14 org.omg.PortableServer.ThreadPolicyOperations - 24 org.omg.PortableServer.ThreadPolicy - 24 org.omg.PortableServer.ThreadPolicyValue - 24 java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor - 24 ThreadLocal - 27 ThreadGroup - 27 ThreadDeath - 27 Thread - 27
new Threa<content assist> ==> java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor - 24 ThreadPoolExecutor() - 24 ThreadPoolExecutor() - 24 ThreadGroup() - 24 Thread() - 24 Thread() - 24 Thread() - 24 ThreadPoolExecutor() - 24 Thread() - 24 Thread() - 24 ThreadPoolExecutor() - 24 Thread() - 24 Thread() - 24 ThreadLocal - 27 ThreadLocal() - 27 ThreadGroup() - 24 ThreadDeath() - 27 java.lang.Thread - 24 Thread() - 24

(In reply to comment #0) > After having selected the type "ThreadLocal", that one even moves to 1st > position. This particular behaviour is a result of the bumped up relevance from JDT/Text for already used proposals from history, and is expected.
I need to figure out what causes the relevance for new Thread() to be lower though.

(In reply to comment #2) > The relevance from JDT Core is too low for those. new Thread() should have the > same relevance as new ThreadDeath() (like in the case of type proposals). Also, > the constructor proposals must have higher relevance than type proposals (as > you can see e.g. ThreadLocal - 27 stands out here). Currently the relevance calculation for type and constructors (in CompletionEngine.proposeType(..) and proposeConstrcuctor(..) ) is exactly the same and so gives identical numbers . This should be differentiated by having a new constant for constructor, which bumps up relevance by say, 3.
Also for ThreadLocal, somehow org.eclipse.jdt.internal.codeassist.CompletionEngine.AcceptedConstructor.mustBeQualified is true and so there's an extra 3 units of relevance related to qualification. This needs to be investigated.

Created attachment 215178 proposed fix v1.0 + regression tests
The fix has 2 parts: 1) Increasing the relevance of constructor proposals in case the assist node is "new ...". this is done using the new method computeRelevanceForConstructor 2) When a proposal comes from an on-demand import, we qualify the name as seen in org.eclipse.jdt.internal.codeassist.CompletionEngine.acceptConstructors(Scope) line 921 onwards. However, the check for on-demand imports was missing at another location, where I've now added it too. This is why ThreadLocal was showing with higher relevance since it had the R_UNQUALIFIED relevance constant added to it. This is fixed now.
Jay, can you please review? Thanks! (Ignore the second part of comment 4)

Created attachment 215316 proposed fix v1.0 + regression tests(updated)
Just updated the test to avoid confusion. Can be ignored if review has already started.

Patch looks good.
I see it's not relevant and this behavior already exists. But why am I seeing ThreadDeath being proposed ahead of Thread without 'new' keyword?

(In reply to comment #9) > I see it's not relevant and this behavior already exists. But why am I seeing > ThreadDeath being proposed ahead of Thread without 'new' keyword?
I don't see it. I see Thread, followed by other proposals. Did you select ThreadDeath anytime before seeing this behaviour? If you did, then ThreadDeath will appear above Thread because its relevance is bumped up by the history. However, for a fresh usage, Thread is the first proposal I see. I also looked at the relevance numbers and Thread, ThreadLocal and ThreadDeath all have 27, which means Thread will come first when sorted alphabetically.

(In reply to comment #10) > I don't see it. I see Thread, followed by other proposals. Did you select > ThreadDeath anytime before seeing this behaviour? If you did, then ThreadDeath > will appear above Thread because its relevance is bumped up by the history. > However, for a fresh usage, Thread is the first proposal I see. I also looked > at the relevance numbers and Thread, ThreadLocal and ThreadDeath all have 27, > which means Thread will come first when sorted alphabetically.
That makes sense. Even though I don't recollect doing it this time, I may have done that in the past.
